description.narrative: Excessive rainfall from extreme precipitation events have Midwestern cities facing serious surface flood risks. The flooding from those extreme precipitation events, which are increasingin both severity and frequency, overwhelms stormwater systems, threatens public health, and damages hundreds of thousands of homes, often in marginalized neighborhoods. Cities like Chicagoand Cleveland are in the midst of decades-long billion dollar capital programs to capture extra stormwater and prevent flooding, but climate change has exacerbated the problems these massive engineering projects were designed to solve. To protect property, health, and the environment, Midwestern urban areas must absorb more rainfall – but in cost-effective, efficient ways. Addressing excess rainfall is expensive and growing problem, but one where resiliency solutions are achievable for communities both large and small.In a dialogue between Dutch experts on the design/planning side, a Dutch expert on the municipal planning/execution side, and a Midwestern municipal official challenges and solutions will be discussed for a broad audience of local Midwest municipal policymakers, urban planners, real estate developers, researchers, utilities, Dutch resiliency tech companies, Dutch engineering and design firms.
